example.title: Basic quotient rule

subsection.title: The quotient rule

example.title: Basic quotient rule
example.p:
Suppose w(x)=\dfrac{x^2+3x+7}{2x^2}. Find w'(x).
\begin{aligned}[t] w'(x) \amp= \frac{d}{dx}\left(\frac{x^2+3x+7}{2x^2}\right)\\ \amp= \frac{(2x^2)\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}\left(x^2+3x+7\right) -(x^2+3x+7)\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}\left(2x^2\right) }{(2x^2)^2}\\ w'(x) \amp= \frac{(2x^2)(2x+3) -(x^2+3x+7)(4x) }{(2x^2)^2}\\ \end{aligned}

subsection.p: This example was written just to practice the technique, so we are not interested in any additional simplification of the final answer. Many of the errors in such a problem are the result of trying to simplify by dividing out what look like, but are not common factors on the right-hand side.

For problems arising in applications, the factoring or simplification is often nicer, but it still takes quite a bit of intuition to ways to group terms in such a complicated expression for the purposes of simplification.
